procedure.title: Generate a sample RESTful web service

important.title: Target runtime must have RESTEasy installed
important.para: The sample RESTful web service will not work unless it is deployed to a server with RESTEasy installed.

step.title: Access the New - Select a wizard dialog

listitem.para: Right click on the project name in the Project Explorer view.
Click the Create a Sample RESTful Web Service label by expanding the Web Services folder.

formalpara.title: Result:
formalpara.para: The New - Select a wizard dialog displays with the selected wizard type highlighted.

step.title: Access the Generate a Sample RESTful Web Service dialog
step.para: Click the Next button to proceed.

formalpara.title: Result:
formalpara.para: The Generate a Sample RESTful Web Service - Project and Web Service Name dialog displays.

figure.title: Generate a Sample RESTful Web Service - Project and Web Service Name

textobject.para: Generate a Sample RESTful Web Service - Project and Web Service Name

step.title: Define the service attributes
step.para: Define the project, web service, package and class names according to the options displayed in

row.entry: The project name will default to the highlighted project in the Project Explorer. A different project can be selected from the list or entered directly in the editable drop-down list
Enter the name for the web service
The web service name will be the url for the service as mapped in the deployment descriptor (web.xml)
Check this box to add the service to the deployment descriptor
This option is checked by default and may be unchecked when deploying to JBoss AS 6.0 or RESTEasy 2.0 servers. Service information is not required in the deployment descriptor for these servers
Enter the package for the web service class
The default package for the sample web service will be displayed
Enter the name of the web service class containing the JAX-RS annotated path

entry.remark: This class defines the path to the web service and is referenced in the Application Class Name. The Application Class Name is declared in the deployment descriptor providing indirect access to the annotated path.

row.entry: Enter the name of the Application Class Name

entry.remark: The Application Class Name constructor instantiates objects of the web service class containing the JAX-RS annotated path, GET and POST methods. It serves as a single point of access to the application for the web server.

step.title: Generate the web service
step.para: Click the Finish button to complete the web service setup.

formalpara.title: Result:
formalpara.para: The web service classes will be generated and the web.xml file updated with the deployment details.

step.title: Browse the MyRESTApplication.java class
step.para: Double click the MyRESTApplication.java class and note the constructor instantiating objects of type HelloWorldResource. The relevance of this will be discussed shortly.

step.title: Browse the HelloWorldResource.java class
step.para: Double click the HelloWorldResource.java class and note the JAX-RS annotated path and the annotated GET method.

step.title: Browse the web.xml deployment descriptor
step.para: Double click the web.xml file and note the jax.ws.rs.Application paramater mapped to the Application Class. Note also:

listitem.para: The main servlet for the application is org.jboss.resteasy.plugins.server.servlet.HttpServletDispatcher which is given the custom name Resteasy.
The main servlet is not mapped to a particular url as indicated by /*.
The url for sending GET requests can be resolved as follows:
identify the Application Class as defined in the deployment descriptor
note the object type instantiated in the Application Class and added to the singleton set HelloWorldResource
note the JAX-RS annotated path declared in the corresponding HelloWorldResource class; @Path("/MyRESTApplication").

step.para: The url for sending GET requests is therefore http://localhost:8080/RestfulSample/MyRESTApplication. Testing RESTful web services is discussed in LINK HERE WHEN DONE.
